channel.title: Suggested Reading – Luna Station Quarterly
channel.description: Stellar Short Fiction by Women-Identified Writers Since 2010

item.title: Suggested Readings by LSQ Authors! Day 7
item.dc:creator: Cheryl Wollner
item.description: It’s been a week long celebration here. Our Five Year Anthology is released, Issue 23…
item.content:encoded:
It’s been a week long celebration here. Our Five Year Anthology is released, Issue 23 is live and full of fantasy and fairy tale magic, and our authors continue to publish incredible things. Thank you for joining our celebration this week. After all, there’s nothing better than discovering your new favorite author.

Kim Mary Trotto‘s novel Goodlands, a teen adventure-romance, is published on Swoon Website. And, make sure to check out her short stories “The Last Memory of Bally” (published in Frontier Tales), Hullabroo (published in Aphelion Webzine), “Well Suited” (published in Defenestration) and of course, “The Gold Fish” published in LSQ.

A. E. Ash published her sci fi poem “Sidereal” in Apex Magazine May 2015.

Allison Har-zvi won first place in the Women’s National Book Association’s annual writing contest! Her winning story “If You’re Ready” is now online in their publication, The Bookwoman. Unlike her work for LSQ, this story doesn’t fall into the speculative fiction category, but, as she says, “I’d be flattered if you wanted to check it out anyway.”

K C Maguire has published her first novel! Check out Inside the Palisade, her YA dystopia story.

If you like what you’re reading, consider getting a copy of our Anthology, and checking out Issue 23. And trust me, with the authors we publish, we’ll always have a few suggested readings and great news to share. Keep reading and keep writing. It’s good for the soul.

item.title: Suggested Readings by LSQ Authors! Day 6
item.dc:creator: Cheryl Wollner
item.description: The days keep rolling by and our authors’ publications keep rolling in. It’s never a…
item.content:encoded:
The days keep rolling by and our authors’ publications keep rolling in. It’s never a bad time to invest in a new story.

Jan Stinchcomb has a new novella, Find the Girl, published March 2015.  Though not speculative fiction, it is a story of mystery and survival, told by a young heroine who is trying to uncover what others keep hidden.

MJ Gardner published her first novel, Evelyn’s Journal. If you like vampires, check it out.

Emma Roz is making her debut feature film as writer/director. The film, Papagajka, is a psychological thriller set in Sarajevo. Synopsis: A stranger arrives in Sarajevo and barges into Damir’s reclusive world. Little by little she takes over his life, even absorbing his dreams, until finally he ceases to exist.

If you like what you’re reading, consider getting a copy of our Anthology, where you can read the work of fifty of our authors and marvel at the cover art by Julie Dillon.

There’ll be more publications to read and more authors to celebrate when our week of suggested reading concludes tomorrow. As always, keep reading and keep writing.

item.title: Suggested Readings By LSQ Authors! Day 5
item.dc:creator: Cheryl Wollner
item.description: What better way to start off your week of work or school or play than…
item.content:encoded:
What better way to start off your week of work or school or play than with an extra helping of reading material? Our week of Suggested Readings by LSQ authors continues to run strong.

Charlotte Nash: her short story “Blue ICE,” an agricultural cyberpunk piece, along with more of her latest publications, can be found on her website.

Tara Campbell was accepted to participate in the 2014 DC Author Festival, sponsored by the District of Columbia Public Library Foundation. Her most recent short story “The Collector” was published in Latchkey Tales Omnibus in June 2015.

Nina Shepardson is a staff reader at Spark: A Creative Anthology.

Maureen Bowden has had 43 poems and short stories accepted for publication by various paying outlets. One of her favorites is her short story “Dead Rocker,” published by Fabula Argen

Congratulations to all our authors for their achievements.

If you like what you’re reading, consider getting a copy of our Anthology, where you can read the work of fifty of our authors and marvel at the cover art by Julie Dillon.

Keep reading and keep writing (it keeps your week fresh)!

item.title: Suggested Reading from LSQ Authors! Day 4
item.dc:creator: Cheryl Wollner
item.description: The weekend’s still kicking and so are we! Our week of Suggested Readings by LSQ…
item.content:encoded:
The weekend’s still kicking and so are we! Our week of Suggested Readings by LSQ authors continues. Happy reading.

Megan Kennedy: her short story “The Waste” is available as an e-book. Come check it out.

Judith Field: take a look at her short story collection: The Book of Judith: Sixteen Tales of Life, Wonder and Magic. You can find out more about Judith and her work through an interview with LSQ to learn more about her featured in our Anthology. You can also follow her LSQ blog posts through her column The Pen Across the Pond.

Carol Holland March: her short story, “The Man Who Watched the Stars”, is available on The Future Fire.

If you like what you’re reading, consider getting a copy of our Anthology, where you can read the work of fifty of our authors and marvel at the cover art by Julie Dillon.

Keep reading and keep writing!

item.title: Suggested Readings from LSQ Authors! Day 3
item.dc:creator: Cheryl Wollner
item.description: Our celebration of LSQ authors doesn’t stop for the weekend. With the publication of our…
item.content:encoded:
Our celebration of LSQ authors doesn’t stop for the weekend. With the publication of our Anthology (celebrating five years of incredible writers from around the world!) we are more thrilled than ever to continue our week of Suggested Readings by LSQ authors. Take a look at these authors’ publications and celebrate their achievements.

Octavia Cade: her short story “Tommy Flowers and the Glass Bells of Bletchley”, a story of magical realism and code-breaking, can be found in The Dark Magazine.

Cathrin Hagey: check out her short story “The Wood Children” in the LSQ Anthology, as well as her short story “Fire and Ice” published in LSQ’s issue 17. You can also find her work featured through her LSQ column: “What’s In a Fairy Tale?”

McKetta: Her new poems coming can be found in The Raintown Review, LiteraryMama, The Coachella Review, and her new writer’s manifesto is published in the anthology CREDO!

Keep reading, keep writing and enjoy your weekend.

item.title: Suggested Reading from LSQ Authors! Day 2
item.dc:creator: Cheryl Wollner
item.description: We’re back with Day 2 of our week long celebration of the amazing work LSQ’s…
item.content:encoded:
We’re back with Day 2 of our week long celebration of the amazing work LSQ’s authors are publishing. Check out this next batch of incredible publications by LSQ authors and the literary journals who published them.

Nikki Vogel: Her work “– in Beginning” was published in Empty Sink Publishing.

Phyllis Green: Since “Violetta Brun” appeared in LSQ, some other stories of hers have been published: “The Little Corner Cafe” in Orion Headless, “Decent People” in Poydras Review, “Ilka and Ivan” in Apeiron Review, “An Arrangement in Scheveningen” in The Milo Review, “Moonlight on the Lake” in Belle Reve, “Cosmetics Counter at Saks” in Bitterzoet, “Morning Traffic” in The McNeese Review, “On the Street Where You Have Never Been Before” in Storyacious and named “Best of Storyacious 2013”, “Our Eyes Met Across a Crowded Room” in Dark Matter, “Teeth” in Gravel, “Chester Drawers” in Goreyesque, “Julia and Drew” in Buried Letter Press, “The Thrill of a Lifetime” in Flapper House, and stories in EDGE, Serving House Journal, WhiskeyPaper, Rose Red Review, Owen Wister Review, and New Plains Review

L.J.Perry: Spent each day of 2014 writing a 100 word drabble. Check out her collection of drabbles here.

Mary E. Lowd: her novel, Otters In Space 2: Jupiter, Deadly, as well as two of her short stories — “In a Cat’s Eyes” and “Fox in the Hen House” — were nominated for the Ursa Major Awards. Her short story “When a Cat Loves a Dog” won for Best Short Fiction, and her stories A Real Stand-Up Guy, The Best Puppy Ever, The Wharf Cat’s Mermaid, and The Carousel of Spirits, were the runners up in the same category. The Ursa Major Awards are meant to reward excellence in anthropomorphic arts and literature — fiction featuring talking animals.

Nancy O’Toole: her short story “The Fox” has been published in the July issue of The Lorelei Signal.

Janel Gradowski: Check out her Culinary Competition mystery series here.

Jan Stinchcomb: for more of Jan’s updates and accomplishments follow her on tumblr and read her book reviews right here on LSQ at Notes From Rapunzel’s Tower.

Keep reading and keep writing! There will be more work from our incredible authors posted for tomorrow.

item.title: Suggested Readings from LSQ authors! Day 1
item.dc:creator: Cheryl Wollner
item.description: Can’t wait to read more from LSQ’s authors? Waiting for your copy of The Best…
item.content:encoded:
Can’t wait to read more from LSQ’s authors? Waiting for your copy of The Best of Luna Station Quarterly to arrive on your doorstep? For a whole week we’ll be sharing additional gems from LSQ authors, celebrating all their writing achievements. Check out these publications by our authors who we certainly couldn’t get enough of.

Terri Deno: published a collection of poetry titled Unfolding Life: A Book of Haiku.

Ann Gimpel: Earth’s Requiem, a full length urban fantasy, was up for a 2014 RONE award from In’D’Tale Magazine. Be sure to check out the second book in the Earth Reclaimed series, Earth’s Blood.

Che Gilson: her novella, Carmine Rojas: Dog Fight was picked up by Black Opal Books.

Sylvia Kelso: her story “Crow” was published in the Spring Equinox 2014 Issue of Eternal Haunted Summer.

Juli D. Revezzo: Drawing Down the Shades is the third installment in her Antique Magic series. Read more about the book (and series) here: http://julidrevezzo.com/regarding-antique-magic/drawing-down-the-shades-tour/.

Danielle E. Shipley: her debut novel, Inspired, is available through J. Taylor Publishing.

Keep reading and keep writing! And remember, more is coming to celebrate the outstanding work of authors published in LSQ.
